text: :: Editor ' s note: This item has been updated to clarify that firearms dealers are required to complete and extract the ATF 4473 form for all types of firearms purchases. Control of the weapon is a controversial subject in the divided Wisconsin Government, with the democratic Government. Tony Evers plans to force the case by inviting the Republican-controlled legislature to a special session. The discussion here and elsewhere usually focuses on two types of legislation, both of which have been implemented in many other states: Red Flag Laws - laws that allow judges to temporarily remove firearms from persons who act dangerously. • Comprehensive background checks. These measures require background checks on sales by private parties, as well as arms dealers, which are already required by federal law. The majority President of the Senate, Scott Fitzgerald, was asked to address this issue on September 22, 2019, his appearance on WISN-TV, "Up Front." He did not see any momentum for Red Flag laws, then modified, and not fast, to the other flash point of arms control. "General background checks, too," said the Republic of Juneo, who recently announced that he was running for a seat in the United States House of Representatives. "I mean, any time you're going to ask someone to present their weapons serial numbers to the state official or federal, he'll violate the second amendment." This raises some questions that merit consideration. People can disagree about whether checking the overall background is a good idea (most people in Wisconsin think so), but we should at least be able to agree on what it is. So, does background checks include the submission of serial numbers to the government? Will this second amendment be violated? How the Fitzgerald office did not respond to our requests for evidence of his claim and further details of his position. However, his response to the television interview indicates that verification of the global background is a record of firearms - where the Government keeps a record of the weapons owned by everyone. It is a common argument from opponents of global background investigations, who consider it a step towards confiscation. But it's an oversimplifying issue. There is no comprehensive formula for verifying the global background, but the basic concept is that private vendors are subject to the same general conditions as licensed arms dealers, including verification of the potential buyer ' s background and maintenance of sales records. Wisconsin is one of 29 states that currently does not need to check the background or record private arms sales. At the federal level, the United States Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives does not regulate private sales and private sales involving licensed firearms dealers. Some states - including California, Colorado, Delaware, Columbia, New York, Oregon, Vermont and Washington - require all private sales through firearms dealers, who then keep sales records, according to the Jefords Legal Centre for the Prevention of Armed Violence, an organization for research and advocacy. They call this the "more inclusive policy option." Other States provide private sellers with the option of resorting directly to law enforcement for background checks. The requirements for record-keeping vary, with some states leaving it to the individual who sells the weapon, and local law enforcement agencies being informed of other cases requiring the transfer of the weapon. Can you buy a gun in Wisconsin after a felony or restraining order? On January 26, 2021, Jim Steinke stated on Republican Twitter that they "come to the table" and were part of a compromise "Give and Take" on the Corona virus bill. • On 27 January 2021 in Wisconsin, any comprehensive background check must be combined with the current firearms sales system, which divides background verification responsibilities based on the type of weapon. The State Department of Justice is responsible for verifying the background of sales of pistols while long arms sales pass through national criminal background verification systems, which are managed by the FBI. What information has been provided to the government, Fitzgerald, that he objects to the verification of the global background due to the new requirements they place on private arms sales, so let's examine what this might look like. If Wisconsin implements a comprehensive background verification system, directing all sales through traders, the flow of information to the authorities will be the same as it is now for the sales of traders. With regard to long arms sales, its dealers fill out form ATF 4473 - which includes the manufacture of arms and serial number - and submit it to the FBI criminal background system. The FBI conducts background checks, but federal law requires that the buyer's identification information and the pistol be destroyed within 24 hours. The merchant is then required to keep a copy of Form 4473 for at least 20 years. After that point, or if the dealer goes from business, the model is delivered to ATF. However, the Federal Act prohibits the anti-terrorist agency from storing such records in searchable form or otherwise using them "to establish any firearms registration system." Records have been maintained using microfilm technology for decades, making weapons tracing a cumbersome manual process. For pistols, Wisconsin traders continue to fill out and maintain form 4473, but background checks are carried out by the Ministry of Justice in Wisconsin. The State law requires traders to submit the name, date of birth, gender, social security number and other identifying information to the Ministry of Justice of Wisconsin. However, the Agency does not receive or store serial numbers or any other information on firearms, as stated by the spokesman for Gillian Drummond. And so, under a comprehensive system, serial numbers can eventually reach a government agency. However, there are usually contracts before this happens, and the Agency is prohibited from converting them into a database. If Wisconsin chooses a less comprehensive system, less information goes to the government. For example, if the State Ministry of Justice is mandated to conduct all background checks on private sales and private vendors are required to keep their own records (as in Illinois), no serial numbers will be provided to any government entity for any special sales of pistols. Will the weapons register violate the Second Amendment? All of this leads us to the final element of Fitzgerald's claim that presenting serial numbers to government officials violates the second amendment. The courts have said that this is not true. Six states and provinces of Colombia already require the registration of some or all firearms, according to the Jefords Law Center. Daniel Webster, Director, Johns Hopkins Center for Arms Policy and Research, said. "Nothing in any Supreme Court ruling to date indicates that the Government's requirement that arms owners provide serial numbers of weapons purchased or owned by them to government officials violates the second amendment." For example, an appeal against the registration requirement in Washington, D.C. in 2015 was largely upheld by a federal Court of Appeal. The provision listed some elements of the law but did not affect the basic requirement of the registration of weapons. Our referee Fitzgerald says that global background checks involve asking people to submit their serial numbers to the government, which would violate the second amendment. The serial numbers provided for background checks do not end in the hands of the government for years or decades. The Federal Agency is therefore prevented from forming it into a database. Moreover, there is no evidence that such a requirement violates the second amendment, since several states have firearms registers that have not been reversed by the courts - a similar provision was upheld by the federal courts in the Washington, D.C. case.
